element.name: Velvet Cache by Windsockers, Multi-cache (2.5/2)

long-description.p: The Velvet Strand is a long sandy beach, approximately 5 km in length, consisting of a large sandy dune area.

It was from here, on June 24th. 1930 that the Southern Cross, piloted by Sir Charles Kingsford Smith with Irishman, Captain Paddy Saul as navigator, flew to Newfoundland on what was the second ever airplane flight across the Atlantic from East to West.

On August 18th. 1932, Jim Mollison, husband of an equally famous woman pilot, Amy Johnson, also left the Velvet Strand in his De Havilland Puss Moth aircraft, The Heart's Content, to attempt the first solo, non-stop East to West crossing of the Atlantic. His aim was to get to New York and his fuel capacity of 160 gallons ensured him of 33 hours continuous flying. However, heavy headwinds forced him to land 30 hours later at Pennfield Ridge, about 30 miles from Saint John, New Brunswick in Canada. He slept in the Admiral Beatty Hotel in Saint John and, the next day, returned to Pennfield to fly his Puss Moth out to the newly constructed Millidgeville airfield (1930) where he refuelled and took off again for New York on August 20th. This flight was acclaimed throughout the World and what cynics had viewed as a foolish venture had, in fact, become a reality. .

The contours of Portmarnock strand change constantly during the year as sand is moved to and fro by storms and wind. Extra beach has been created at the southern end of the beach. A feature over the last few years has been the deterioration of the sand dunes behind the strand. .
Have a read of the information board nearby and find how many hours it took the flight till it landed in Harbour Grace call this number A.B.C
Also take note of the year the statue was commemorated call the last digit D
Take note of the number of letters in the name of “Charlie’Ulms” plane call this E.F
At this location note the amount of meter’s mentioned call this G.H.I
At this location note the amount of meter’s mentioned call this J
At this location note the number of letters on the bottom sign call this K
The Cache can be found at

On discovery of the cache don’t try to remove to entire container from its location
Please beware of the muggles in this area and rehide the cache properly to prevent them from discovering its location

element.additional-waypoints:
FN185T5 - GC185T5 Final

Take note of the number of letters in the name of “Charlie Ulms” plane call this E.F

At this location note the amount of meter’s mentioned call this G.H.I
S4185T5 - GC185T5 Stage 4
N 53° 25.437 W 006° 07.373
At this location note the amount of meter’s mentioned call this J
S5185T5 - GC185T5 Stage 5
N 53° 25.071 W 006° 07.237
At this location note the number of letters on the bottom sign call this K

ul.li:
2010-05-15T19:00:00Z : Found it by Alastair74
Found with Wildfowler while spending the day in Dublin for the WWFM. TFTC

2010-05-15T19:00:00Z : Found it by wildfowler
Painfully found on a caching weekend around Dublin with Alastair74! TNLNSL TFTC

2010-02-13T17:31:09Z : Found it by hollmanr
Found it easily which was more down to it being in the first place we looked :-). Lovely day and lovely walk on the beach. SL TN TFTC.

2009-09-13T19:00:00Z : Didn't find it by abra123cadabra
Sad to say, we didn't find it. Maybe we're blind [:(]. I'm sure we've got the coordinates for the final location but the GPSr wouldn't settle and after searching in all possible thorny locations around GZ we gave up. This is very disappointing as it was a really long walk along the beach and back to the car.

2009-08-28T19:00:00Z : Didn't find it by Team KVS
We had a really nice walkalong the beach, just a shame the hiding place wasn't upto the same standard. With a heavy downpoor just passed, none of us was interested to search very much at the final location.
Mummy & Pappa

groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:name: Velvet Cache
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:long_description:
The Velvet Strand is a long sandy beach, approximately 5 km in length, consisting of a large sandy dune area.

It was from here, on June 24th. 1930 that the Southern Cross, piloted by Sir Charles Kingsford Smith with Irishman, Captain Paddy Saul as navigator, flew to Newfoundland on what was the second ever airplane flight across the Atlantic from East to West.

On August 18th. 1932, Jim Mollison, husband of an equally famous woman pilot, Amy Johnson, also left the Velvet Strand in his De Havilland Puss Moth aircraft, The Heart's Content, to attempt the first solo, non-stop East to West crossing of the Atlantic. His aim was to get to New York and his fuel capacity of 160 gallons ensured him of 33 hours continuous flying. However, heavy headwinds forced him to land 30 hours later at Pennfield Ridge, about 30 miles from Saint John, New Brunswick in Canada. He slept in the Admiral Beatty Hotel in Saint John and, the next day, returned to Pennfield to fly his Puss Moth out to the newly constructed Millidgeville airfield (1930) where he refuelled and took off again for New York on August 20th. This flight was acclaimed throughout the World and what cynics had viewed as a foolish venture had, in fact, become a reality. .

The contours of Portmarnock strand change constantly during the year as sand is moved to and fro by storms and wind. Extra beach has been created at the southern end of the beach. A feature over the last few years has been the deterioration of the sand dunes behind the strand. .

The Cache

Stage 1

Have a read of the information board nearby and find how many hours it took the flight till it landed in Harbour Grace call this number A.B.C

Also take note of the year the statue was commemorated call the last digit D

Stage 2

Take note of the number of letters in the name of “Charlie’Ulms” plane call this E.F

Stage 3

At this location note the amount of meter’s mentioned call this G.H.I

Stage 4

At this location note the amount of meter’s mentioned call this J

Stage 5

At this location note the number of letters on the bottom sign call this K

Final Location

The Cache can be found at

N53 DJ.HA(D+F)

W 006 I(C+D)(K-F)(B+E)C

On discovery of the cache don’t try to remove to entire container from its location
Please beware of the muggles in this area and rehide the cache properly to prevent them from discovering its location


The Windsockers

Additional Waypoints

groundspeak:log.groundspeak:text: Found with Wildfowler while spending the day in Dublin for the WWFM. TFTC
Painfully found on a caching weekend around Dublin with Alastair74! TNLNSL TFTC
Found it easily which was more down to it being in the first place we looked :-). Lovely day and lovely walk on the beach. SL TN TFTC.

Sad to say, we didn't find it. Maybe we're blind [:(]. I'm sure we've got the coordinates for the final location but the GPSr wouldn't settle and after searching in all possible thorny locations around GZ we gave up. This is very disappointing as it was a really long walk along the beach and back to the car.

We had a really nice walkalong the beach, just a shame the hiding place wasn't upto the same standard. With a heavy downpoor just passed, none of us was interested to search very much at the final location.
Mummy & Pappa
